t: Ecclesiastes 5
Fulfill Your Vow to God
Guard*p your steps when you go to the house of God. Go near to listen rather than to offer the sacrifice of fools, who do not know that they do wrong.
Do*pn not be quick with your mouth, do*ld not be hasty in your heart to*ld utter anything before God. God*ln is in heaven and*ld you are on earth, so*ld let your words be few.
A*ln dream comes when there are many cares, and*ld many words mark the speech of a fool.
When*p you make a vow to God, do not delay to fulfill it. He has no pleasure in fools; fulfill your vow.
It is better not to make a vow than to make one and not fulfill it.
Do not let your mouth lead you into sin. And do not protest to the temple messenger, “My vow was a mistake.” Why should God be angry at what you say and destroy the work of your hands?
Much dreaming and many words are meaningless. Therefore fear God.
Riches Are Meaningless
If*p you see the poor oppressed in a district, and justice and rights denied, do not be surprised at such things; for one official is eyed by a higher one, and over them both are others higher still.
The increase from the land is taken by all; the king himself profits from the fields.
Whoever*pn loves money never has enough; whoever*ld loves wealth is never satisfied with their income. This*ld too is meaningless.
As*pn goods increase, so*ld do those who consume them. And*ln what benefit are they to the owners except*ld to feast their eyes on them?
The*pn sleep of a laborer is sweet, whether*ld they eat little or much, but*ln as for the rich, their abundance permits*ld them no sleep.
I*p have seen a grievous evil under the sun: wealth*pn hoarded to the harm of its owners,
or*ld wealth lost through some misfortune, so*ln that when they have children there*ld is nothing left for them to inherit.
Everyone*ln comes naked from their mother’s womb, and*ld as everyone comes, so they depart. They*ln take nothing from their toil that*ld they can carry in their hands.
This*p too is a grievous evil: As*pn everyone comes, so they depart, and*ld what do they gain, since*ld they toil for the wind?
All*ln their days they eat in darkness, with*ld great frustration, affliction and anger.

This*p is what I have observed to be good: that it is appropriate for a person to eat, to drink and to find satisfaction in their toilsome labor under the sun during the few days of life God has given them—for this is their lot.
Moreover, when God gives someone wealth and possessions, and the ability to enjoy them, to accept their lot and be happy in their toil—this is a gift of God.
They seldom reflect on the days of their life, because God keeps them occupied with gladness of heart.
